intro: Hygrophila tumbuctuensis, commonly known as the Senegal waterweed, is a flowering plant native to tropical Africa. It is a semi-aquatic species that typically grows in wetlands, marshes, and along the edges of water bodies. The plant has slender, branching stems that are often submerged, with small, opposite leaves that are usually elliptical in shape. It produces small, clustered flowers that are usually yellow or greenish-yellow, which bloom during the rainy season. Hygrophila tumbuctuensis plays an important role in aquatic ecosystems by providing habitat and food for various aquatic organisms.
